title: About the Women+ in Early Career Research Group
text: We are a cross-institutional network dedicated to supporting researchers at the beginning of their academic research careers. Our diverse membership spans multiple disciplines—from Computer Science and Immunology to Sociology and Information Science. We represent institutions across the broader Dublin area, including TU Dublin, Trinity College Dublin, UCD, DCU, and DKIT. Our community is open to all early career researchers, specifically PhD candidates, postdoctoral researchers, and lecturers in the first 1–3 years of their appointment.

title: About the Women+ in Early Career Research Group
text: We are a cross-institutional network dedicated to supporting researchers at the beginning of their academic research careers. Our diverse membership spans multiple disciplines—from Computer Science and Immunology to Sociology and Information Science. We represent institutions across the broader Dublin area, including TU Dublin, Trinity College Dublin, UCD, DCU, and DKIT. Our community is open to all early career researchers, specifically PhD candidates, postdoctoral researchers, and lecturers in the first 1–3 years of their appointment.

title: About the Women+ in Early Career Research Group
text:
Our Mission
Research can often be a solitary pursuit and women+ researchers face unique challenges, including the leaky pipeline where the number of women seen in higher positions decreases (WREN and Science Policy Review). We aim to break down silos and systemic challenges by building a vibrant, effective research community in Dublin and the surrounding areas. By being women+ centred, we aim to address the structural and cultural barriers that disproportionately affect women and gender-diverse researchers at the start of their careers. By fostering an interdisciplinary environment, we move beyond subject-specific bubbles to focus on academic skills: rigorous research practices, effective writing, presentation skills, and career navigation.
We support our community with these skills as well as with building strong interdisciplinary networks and robust peer-mentorships that can reduce the effect of the leaky pipeline.

title: About the Women+ in Early Career Research Group
text:
What Do We Do?
Our goal is to collaborate and support one another through our early careers in research in a variety of different activities. We hope to achieve this via a curated schedule of events including:

International Women’s Day Research Symposium focusing on the research being conducted by our members with abstracts published on ARROW@TU Dublin.
Workshops ranging from academic writing and poster design and development to half day focused writing sessions.
Community support via active WhatsApp group and monthly in-person coffee socials in Dublin.

title: Women+ ECR Symposium
text:
On the 6th of March 2026, to celebrate International Women’s Day, we will hold our first Women+ in Early Career Research Symposium at TU Dublin’s city campus. The aim of this symposium is to create a supportive, inclusive space to showcase research, foster cross-disciplinary dialogue, and build networks among women and gender-diverse researchers at early career stages.
We invite paper submissions from early-career women+ researchers across disciplines, including STEM, humanities, health, creative practice, and interdisciplinary work. We especially encourage submissions from researchers whose voices are underrepresented in academia, including those from marginalized backgrounds, caregiving roles, regional institutions, and non-traditional career pathways.
Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the symposium, researchers outside your field may be reviewing your paper; for this reason, we ask all papers, presentations, and posters to be pitched at a broad scientific audience level. All accepted papers will be published on Arrow TU Dublin’s Open Access institutional repository. There will be no charge for publishing on Arrow.

title: Women+ ECR Symposium
text:
Who Can Submit

Early career researchers including but not limited to PhD candidates, postdoctoral researchers or those in their first 10 years of research
Women and gender-diverse researchers (including trans, non-binary, genderqueer)
Researchers from any institution or discipline on the Island of Ireland

title: Women+ ECR Symposium
text:
Presentation Formats

Lightning talks (5 min)

1st-year PhD track (5 min)

Oral presentations (10 min)

Posters

title: Women+ ECR Symposium
text:
Submissions
Length:
1–3 pages (including references)
Style:
Submissions should be written as an accessible science communication piece for a broad scientific audience.
Format:
Please use the LaTeX template provided. ⬇ Download the LaTeX template
Research Areas:
Research area tells us what areas you feel represents your submission best. We accept submissions for all areas such as (but not limited to:)

Natural & Physical Sciences: Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Earth & Environmental Sciences
Life Sciences & Health: Biology, Medicine, Public Health, Psychology, Neuroscience
Engineering & Digital: Engineering, Computer Science, AI, Data Science, Robotics
Social Sciences & Policy: Economics, Sociology, Political Science, Development & Public Policy
Humanities, Arts & Culture: History, Philosophy, Literature, Media, Design, Cultural Studies
Business, Education & Law: Management, Entrepreneurship, Education Research, Governance, Law

How to Submit:
To submit a paper you must complete the submission form and email the PDF paper submission to andrea.c.heaney@mytudublin.ie Open submission form Please note once you download the template please upload the zip to Overleaf (or whatever you use to open Latex files). There is a “Source” folder and a “write in this folder”, you should edit the “UseMe.tex” to write your submission. The “Source” folder will give it structure for you. You may wish to upload a .bib file if you wish to add references.
Publication:
Accepted papers will be published through ARROW. Each paper will have an individual DOI.
Reviewers:
We would like to request that with each submission one author volunteers to review.

title: Women+ ECR Symposium
section: Attending the Women+ in ECR Symposium
text:
Attending the Women+ in ECR Symposium
Location
TU Dublin’s city campus, exact location TBC
Who can Attend
Any gender at any stage of their research career, once you have a ticket.
How to get a Ticket
We will have a limited number of tickets available on eventbrite. A link will be added here once they are available. For organisational and catering purposes we ask if you can no longer attend that you cancel your ticket.

title: Women+ ECR Symposium
text:
Key Dates

Submission deadline: 9th February 2026 at 11.59pm IST
Notification of acceptance: 25th of February 2026
Symposium date: 6 March 2026

title: Contacts
text:
For general queries about the Women+ ECR Symposium and the Women + in ECR group, please contact: Elizabeth Darnell elizabeth.g.darnell@mytudublin.ie
For queries about submitting and publishing with the Women+ ECR Symposium, please contact: Andrea Heaney andrea.c.heaney@mytudublin.ie
